item.title: Armed Man Is Fatally Shot at Mar-a-Lago, Secret Service Says
item.content:encoded: The man was killed early Sunday after an “unauthorized entry” into the secure perimeter at President Trump’s resort in Florida, the agency said. The president was not at the club at the time.

item.title: Denmark Rejects Trump’s Plan to Send Hospital Boat to Greenland
item.content:encoded: Denmark’s defense minister said Greenland did not need health care assistance, a day after President Trump said he planned to send a “great hospital boat” to the island.

item.title: Trump Tensions Turn U.S.-Canada Olympic Hockey Final Into a ‘Grudge Match’
item.content:encoded: Amid growing cross-border political animosity, the game meant even more than usual to Canadian fans who had flown in for one of the marquee events of the Winter Games.

item.title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
item.content:encoded: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.

item.title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
item.content:encoded: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.

item.title: Newsom, Targeting Red States, Kicks Off Book Tour in Nashville
item.content:encoded: Scores of Californians have moved to Tennessee for its friendlier business environment and conservative politics. On Saturday, the Democratic governor accused of driving them away paid a visit.

item.title: The Ex-Taxi Driver at the Center of Russia’s Shadow War
item.content:encoded: The Kremlin’s sabotage campaign against European allies of Ukraine has been escalating. It needs people like Aleksei Kolosovsky, 42, to carry it out.

item.title: You Can Bet on It
item.content:encoded: Today, a Morning writer explains how he became a grudging participant in the world of online gambling.

item.title: Here Are the Five Biggest Snowstorms in New York City Since 1869
item.content:encoded: This week’s storm, which is expected to bring 12 to 20 inches of snow to the city, has prompted the first blizzard warning issued for the city since 2017.

item.title: Russia Attacks Ukraine Ahead of Invasion’s 4th Anniversary
item.content:encoded: At least one man was killed in Kyiv as Moscow launched a wave of drones and missiles, days after the latest round of U.S.-mediated talks to end the war.

item.title: Is This the Most Important Supreme Court Case of the Century?
item.content:encoded: The tariff ruling may have just helped save the Republic.

item.title: Is the Swipe Era Over?
item.content:encoded: Meet the new (and old) ways we’re finding love in 2026.

item.title: Inside Iran’s Preparations for War and Plans for Survival
item.content:encoded: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has entrusted Ali Larijani, the top national security official, to ensure the Islamic Republic endures any military attacks and targeted killings.

item.title: At Least 15 Have Died on Tahoe-Area Slopes This Year
item.content:encoded: Three more skiers have died in the Lake Tahoe area since the deadliest avalanche in California history on Tuesday killed nine.

item.title: Should I Tell My Housekeeper, ‘I’m Here for You’?
item.content:encoded: Plus, what to do when your job interviewer spouts off on things better left unsaid.

item.title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
item.content:encoded: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?

item.title: They Killed Their Abusers. Should They Spend Their Lives in Prison?
item.content:encoded: A new law was supposed to help reduce the sentences of survivors of domestic violence. Most are still behind bars.

item.title: A Roving Reporter on the Future of Transit in New York City
item.content:encoded: “A lot of interesting things happening in the city involve how people get around,” said Stefanos Chen, a Metro reporter and lifelong bus aficionado.

item.title: Inside the Big Tech Lobbying Machine Aiming to Halt Social Media Bans
item.content:encoded: Tech giants, including Meta and Alphabet, are spending lavishly on splashy billboard ads, courting on-the-fence politicians and bulking up their ranks of lobbyists.

item.title: Ukraine Has Passed a Point of No Return
item.content:encoded: Four years that changed everything.

item.title: How the Times Weather Team Tracks Big Storms: More Data, Less Hype
item.content:encoded: When making forecasts, our reporters aim to visualize severe weather possibilities rather than focus on the most dire predictions. A possible blizzard this weekend is the latest test.

item.title: Willie Colón, a Luminary of Salsa Music, Dies at 75
item.content:encoded: A trombonist, singer, bandleader, composer and arranger, he collaborated with Rubén Blades on “Siembra,” a 1978 release that became one of the top-selling salsa albums of all time.

item.title: New York Nurses’ Strike Ends After 6 Weeks as Last Holdouts Approve Deal
item.content:encoded: Workers at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital voted for a contract with raises and layoff protections, meaning more than 4,000 nurses will return.

item.title: Traveling This Weekend? Here’s What to Know About the Snowstorm.
item.content:encoded: A major winter storm on Sunday and Monday is expected to bring delays and cancellations across much of the Northeast.

item.title: Trump Doubles Down on Closing Tax Loophole on Cheap Imports
item.content:encoded: The exemption was shut down last year by President Trump based, in part, on the same legal grounds as the tariffs that were invalidated by the Supreme Court.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Global Tariff to 15 Percent
item.content:encoded: The move signaled that the president would press ahead with steep global import taxes despite the legal setback from the Supreme Court.

item.title: JPMorgan Admits to Debanking Trump After Jan. 6 Capitol Attacks
item.content:encoded: Nation’s largest bank, in response to a lawsuit filed by the president, confirmed his longstanding complaint about “debanking.”

item.title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
item.content:encoded: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it

item.title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
item.content:encoded: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it

item.title: The Queen Stuck by Prince Andrew. King Charles Is Pulling Away
item.content:encoded: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the former prince, is getting no help from the throne as the crisis over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein intensifies.

item.title: After Tariff Decision, What Happens to Trump’s Deals With China, Canada and Europe?
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s decision to invalidate many of President Trump’s tariffs raised questions about what would become of agreements struck with major U.S. trading partners.

item.title: Businesses Celebrate Tariff Relief, And Brace for New Uncertainty
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s ruling against many of President Trump’s tariffs cheered executives who set to work seeking refunds on their duties.

item.title: Six Questions on the Future of Trump’s Tariffs
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s ruling on the president’s tariffs has jolted Washington and the business world. Here’s what to watch next.

item.title: With Tariff Changes, Consumers May Be Stuck in a Waiting Game
item.content:encoded: Some companies could decide to temper price increases, but the effect would take time to materialize.

item.title: ‘Murky Waters’ for Global Businesses After Trump’s Tariff Loss
item.content:encoded: Even after the Supreme Court invalidated many of the president’s levies, foreign leaders and executives assume that U.S. tariffs are here to stay, in one form or another.

item.title: He Researched Dishonesty. He Got Friendly With Jeffrey Epstein.
item.content:encoded: Dan Ariely, a behavioral scientist at Duke, sought out the convicted sex offender for his research. Their yearslong correspondence suggests it wasn’t all business.

item.title: For India, Buying Russian Oil Just Got More Complicated
item.content:encoded: India’s prime minister acceded to many of President Trump’s demands under pressure of heavy tariffs. It would be awkward to reject them now.

item.title: Fred Segal Has a New Owner. This Time It’s Aritzia.
item.content:encoded: The storied Los Angeles retailer, once recognized as an arbiter of West Coast style, has been acquired by the mass-market brand Aritzia.

item.title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
item.content:encoded: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.

item.title: Who Is Not Funding This Antarctic Expedition?
item.content:encoded: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong describes America’s shifting relationship with polar research amid the threat of rising sea levels.

item.title: Ask The Morning: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: The justices struck down a central piece of President Trump’s agenda. What does that mean?

item.title: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling to Spur Chaotic Refund Process
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration says it could take years and additional litigation for importers to get their money back.

item.title: Tariff Whiplash Clouds Outlook for Federal Budget
item.content:encoded: The tariffs thrown out by the Supreme Court had become an important revenue source. President Trump said he could replace that money with other levies.

item.title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
item.content:encoded: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.

item.title: Mixed Signals Churn Stock Market Despite Recent Highs
item.content:encoded: Major indexes have mostly been treading water for months, as investors’ exuberance for artificial intelligence wears off.

item.title: Supreme Court Justices Strike Down Trump’s Tariffs
item.content:encoded: President Trump was the first to invoke the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to set tariffs on imported goods from more than 100 countries.

item.title: A Cancer Detection Test Fails in Major Study
item.content:encoded: A closely watched clinical trial in Britain that screened blood for early detection of cancer did not show a reduction in diagnoses at later stages of the disease.

item.title: Some Reese’s Treats Drop the Milk Chocolate. Mr. Reese Disapproves.
item.content:encoded: With cocoa prices high, Hershey’s has changed some of its candy recipes. The grandson of the man who invented the original Peanut Butter Cup said he was “embarrassed.”

item.title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
item.content:encoded: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.

item.title: Trump and Indonesia Sign Trade Deal, Locking In 19% Tariffs
item.content:encoded: The countries made official an agreement reached last year, with Indonesia avoiding a higher tariff and committing to cooperate on export controls.

item.title: U.S. Economy Grew Modestly at End of 2025
item.content:encoded: Gross domestic product expanded at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of the year, hit by the effects of the government shutdown.

item.title: Can an A.I. Productivity Boom Clear a Path for More Rate Cuts? Trump’s Fed Pick Thinks So.
item.content:encoded: As Federal Reserve chair, Kevin M. Warsh may face a tough task persuading his colleagues to lower borrowing costs because of potential productivity gains.

item.title: Is Blue Owl Private Credit’s ‘Canary in the Coal Mine’?
item.content:encoded: Steep declines in the shares of private lenders, after a major fund changed how investors can withdraw money, have sparked worries about more trouble to come.

item.title: Blue Owl Capital Sets Off New Fears About the Private Credit Industry
item.content:encoded: The lender’s announcement that investors will no longer be able to ask for a set amount of money back from its funds prompted worries about the private credit industry.

item.title: Trump Administration Uses ‘Equal Time’ Rule to Reshape Late-Night TV
item.content:encoded: The F.C.C. is using the “equal time” provision to take aim at hosts like Stephen Colbert. The impact could reshape how talk shows handle politics.

item.title: Labor Secretary’s Husband Barred From Department Premises After Reports of Sexual Assaults
item.content:encoded: At least two female staff members said Dr. Shawn DeRemer had touched them inappropriately at the agency in Washington.

item.title: In 2025, Trade Deficit in Goods Reached Record High
item.content:encoded: Data released Thursday by the Census Bureau showed the overall trade deficit with the world narrowed, the result of an expanding trade surplus in services. The trade deficit in goods was the highest on record.

item.title: On an Ambitious Antarctic Quest, One Nation Is on the Sidelines
item.content:encoded: None of the main research on the voyage of the Araon was funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation, a sign of the difficult times for American science.

item.title: Bill Gates Cancels Speech in India Amid Epstein Controversy
item.content:encoded: The philanthropist made the announcement on Thursday, after having earlier confirmed his participation in a prominent artificial intelligence summit in India.

item.title: Doing Your Taxes? We Want to Hear From You.
item.content:encoded: The New York Times is looking to speak to Americans about how the most recent tax cuts are affecting their pocketbooks.

item.title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
item.content:encoded: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.

item.title: Trump Mulls a North American Trade Pact Without Canada
item.content:encoded: U.S. officials are threatening major changes to a trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that could upend the way business is done and leave Canada on the outs.

item.title: Walmart Expects Growth Streak to Continue as New Chief Takes Over
item.content:encoded: Shoppers are turning to Walmart to stretch their dollars, but an uncertain economy and trade tensions will test the retailer’s new executive team.

item.title: Jittery Markets Seek an Iran ‘Off-Ramp’
item.content:encoded: Oil prices spiked and stocks fell as tensions between Washington and Tehran unnerved investors.

item.title: Uber Moves to Enact Stricter Background Checks for Drivers
item.content:encoded: The New York Times revealed in December that the ride-hailing giant approved drivers with many types of criminal convictions, including violent felonies.

item.title: Ring’s Founder Knows You Hated That Super Bowl Ad
item.content:encoded: Since the commercial aired, Jamie Siminoff has been trying to quell an outcry over privacy concerns with his doorbell cameras.

item.title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
item.content:encoded: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.

item.title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
item.content:encoded: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.content:encoded: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.

item.title: Workplace Inspections by OSHA Dropped Over a Six-Month Period of 2025
item.content:encoded: Labor advocates worry that the Trump administration is relaxing oversight of companies and increasing the potential for serious injuries and deaths.
